repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Rwanda - Poverty Reduction
            Support Series four to seven

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Four to Seven Series
            Poverty Reduction Support Project for Republic of Rwanda
            were as follows: outcome was satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned include: second poverty reduction
            support financing (PRSF) series proved to be effective in
            advancing government-owned reforms. The PRSF series has
            provided important support to the Government to
            operationalize its ambitious medium-term development
            strategy i.e., the economic development and poverty
            reduction strategy (EDPRS) by translating its objectives
            into priority actions. The PRSF series provided substantial
            financing to Rwanda's budget, including during the 2008
            crisis. It was successful in fostering better donor
            coordination, improved harmonization and reinforced support
            for reforms among the country's budget support donors:
            the World Bank, African Development Bank, and bilateral
            donors -all partners in the Budget Support Harmonization
            Group and part of the semi-annual joint budget support
            reviews (JBSR). PRSF series focused on capacity building,
            including sub-national levels of government in planning. The
            success of the PRSF series was also largely helped by its
            ability to base its design on strong sector dialogue. This
            has helped to: (i) ensure the PRSF reflects substantive
            policy agreements reached at the sector level; (ii)
            strengthen the capacity of sector ministries to present
            their needs and priorities during national level policy
            discussions and budget negotiations; and (iii) facilitate
            coordination of the Bank's inputs into the common
            performance assessment framework (CPAF) policy discussions
            in a timely manner. Considering the preparation and
            implementation of the series coincided with the CPAF
            establishment in 2008, this period can be regarded as a
            transition or learning period for all parties involved in
            budget support in Rwanda. Also, growing mutual understanding
            of what each partner would need to get out of the process
            helped it to become smoother over time.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Fifth Poverty Reduction Strategy
            Support Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Poverty Reduction Support
            Grant (PRSG-5) continues to support the Government of Rwanda
            (GoR) as it implements measures to foster broad based growth
            in the context of enhanced decentralization reforms. PRSG-5
            is the second operation in the second series of PRSGs.
            PRSG-5 focuses on reforms to ease human capital and
            infrastructure constraints to growth, foster fiscal
            decentralization, and strengthen the results orientation of
            the Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF) and the budget
            process. Continued capacity support to enable implementation
            of reforms to financial management and the budget and
            procurement frameworks is also envisioned. Overall, the
            operation will emphasize support for reforms that promote
            increased spending efficiency, to lay the foundation for
            increased absorption and effectiveness of higher aid
            inflows. This program document outlines the components of
            the operation. Discussion of the country context in section
            two focuses on economic developments in realizing key
            outcomes targeted by the EDPRS. Section three outlines the
            GoR's program followed by the discussion of the
            Bank's support to the GoR's strategy in section
            four. Section five describes the areas to be supported under
            PRSG-5. Section six concludes with an overview of the
            implementation arrangements, benefits and risks of the
            proposed operation.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Fourth Poverty Reduction Strategy
            Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Poverty Reduction Strategy
            Grant Project (PRSG-4) for Rwanda continues to support the
            Government of Rwanda (GoR) as it implements the next steps
            in its reform program to support growth, now being
            undertaken in the context of enhanced decentralization
            reforms. Within this context, the PRSG-4 is expected to help
            the GoR to : 1) maintain a stable macroeconomic framework,
            put in place reforms to ease the human capital and
            infrastructure constraints to growth, with the aim of
            creating a strong basis for private sector-led economic
            growth, driven by agricultural transformation, promotion of
            exports, deepening of the financial sector, and the use o f
            information communications technology; 2) strengthen further
            the linkages between strategic planning and the Medium-Term
            Expenditure Framework (MTEF), by broadening the focus on
            service delivery to include more strongly the agriculture,
            transport, and financial sectors, while continuing to
            maintain and deepen the progress made in the education,
            health, water, and energy sectors; and 3) continue improving
            governance and transparency through capacity support to
            enable implementation of completed reforms to financial
            management, and the budget and procurement frameworks, with
            a particular emphasis on strengthening the process of fiscal
            decentralization. Expected benefits are as follows: 1) in
            creased access to infrastructure services while continuing
            to consolidate and improve access to education and health
            services to increase the supply of skilled labor in the
            workforce; 2) improved efficiency of spending by supporting
            reforms to strengthen the MTEF and public procurement
            process; 3) strengthened capacity to implement through
            support to civil service reforms to improve ministerial
            structures and provide incentives to staff, increase skills
            of the civil service and reduce turn-over.
